prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to investigate rotation and infall of enveloeps and disks around low-mass protostars, ~0.1 km/s velocity resoluition is necessary. This is the right choice based on our previous ALMA observations as well.

Because the compact SO emissions we detected in our ALMA cycle 0 observatins were not spatially resolved at a ~0.8" resolution, we request a resolution of 0.2" this time. According to our model calculations, the sizes of the holes of the SO rings are ~50 AU, corresponding to ~0.4". In order to clearly detecte these holes, we also need such a high angular resolution.
The largest scale we would like to observe is 8", corresponding to ~1000 AU. This is because we would like to perform LVG calculations to investigate physical conditions of C18O envelopes as well as SO rings with less missing flux. C18O envelopes have a size-scale of ~8" according to our previous ALMA observations. Note that the C18O envelopes associated with our targets must have much larger sizes (~10,000 AU), which cannnot be recovered by the proposed observations. However, it is OK for our purpose beceause our LVG analysis will focus on the inner regions of the envelopes.

We estimated the liine intensities of SO lines, which are weaker than C18O lines, based on the ALMA cycle 0 observations. Simple models were constructed to explain the hot ring structure in thr cycle 0 observastions. We calculated the linie intensities of three SO liines with our models, and simulated the ALMA cycle 3 observations. According to our simulations, SO 3_3-3_2 is the weakest line among the SO lines. In the case of L1527 IRS, the sensitivity of ~10 mJy is required to detect the SO 3_3-3-2 line above 5sigma level over the velocity range of +-1.5 km/s

In order to investigate rotation and infall of envelopes and disks around low-mass protostars, ~0.1 km/s velocity resolution is necessary. This is the right choice beased on our previous ALMA observations as well.

Because the compact SO emissions we detected in our syscle 0 observations were not spatially resolved at a ~0.8" resolution, we request a resolution of 0.2" this time. According to our model calculations, the sizes of the holes of the SO emissions are ~50 AU, corresponding to ~0.4". In order to clearly image these holes, we also need such a high angular resolution.
The largest scale we would like to observe is 8", corresponding to ~1000 AU. This is because we would ike to perform LVG calculations to investigate physical conditions of C18O envelopes as well as SO rings with less missing flux. C18O envelopes have a size-scale of ~8" according to our previous ALMA observations. Note that the C18O envelopes associated with our targets must have much larger sizes (~10,000 AU), which cannot be recovered by the proposed observations. However, it is OK for our purpose because LVG analysis will focus on the inner regions of the envelopes.

We estimated the line intensities of SO lines based on the ALMA cycle 0 observations. Simple models were constructed to explain the hot ring structure in the cycle 0 observations. We calculated the line intensities of three SO lines with our models, and simulated the ALMA cycle 3 observations. According to our simulations, SO 6_5-5_4 emission can be ditected above 5 sigma level over the velocity range of +-1.5 km/s with a sensitivity of ~10 mJy/beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This is the resubmission of the previously approve ALMA Cycle 2 proposal (2013.1.01086.S). We propsoe to use ALMA to investigate physical propoerties of possible "hot" rings we found in our ALMA Cycle 0 observations. In our ALMA cycle 0 observations of young protostars in Taurus, we have detected intriguing SO emission associated with Kepleriand disks surrouding the protostars. The SO emission is rotates in the same manner as the associated C18O envelopes and disks, but their velocity patterns are quite different from those of the envelopes and disks. Our model suggests that the SO emission srizes from hot rings, which may be formed with accretion shocks. In this proposal, we plan to observe multi transitions of the SO lines as well as C18O lines in band 6 and band 7 at 0.2" resolutios to invetigate physical conditions of the SO emiiting regions and to reveal the origin of the SO emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00210.S, Probing Formation of Keplerian Disks around Protostars, PI: Nagayoshi Ohashi 2012.1.00647.S, Probing Formation of Keplerian Disks around Protostars, PI: Nagayoshi Ohashi 2013.1.01086.S, Physical Properties of Possible "Hot" Rings around Protostars, PI: Shin Koyamatsu
